stem: A 32-year-old trauma client has received 12 liters of IV crystalloids for hemorrhagic shock over the last 6 hours. Based on the documentation and clinical findings, which indicates the need for emergent surgical decompression?

options.text: Intra-abdominal pressure of 28 mmHg with acute oliguria.

rationale.correct: The client has developed Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS) (a1). High-volume fluid resuscitation causes bowel swelling and fluid shifts into the peritoneum. When the intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) exceeds 20 mmHg and causes new organ dysfunction (oliguria: 4 mL/hr, high airway pressures: 48 cm H2O), emergent surgical laparotomy is indicated to relieve the pressure. Untreated, the pressure will compress the inferior vena cava (IVC), reducing preload, and the kidneys, decreasing urine output.
clinicalPearls: IAP is measured via a transducer on a Foley catheter (bladder pressure).
ACS is common in massive fluid resuscitation, burns, or abdominal trauma.
High airway pressures occur because the swollen abdomen pushes the diaphragm into the chest, limiting lung expansion.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'Board-like rigidity' (a4) because it suggests peritonitis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the abdomen is firm, the indicator for decompression in ACS is a specific measurement (pressure > 20 mmHg) relative to organ status. Prioritize objective measurements when evaluating for surgical intervention.

mnemonic.title: Belly-Tight
mnemonic.expansion: Pressures high. Urine low. Lungs can't blow. Open the belly!

exhibits.title: Clinical Findings
exhibits.content: Current: Abdomen is tense and board-like (distended). Urine output has decreased from 30 mL/hr to 4 mL/hr. Client on ventilator: Tidal volume is decreasing; PCO2 is rising to 58 mmHg.
